address.deliveryPoint: Dept of Earth and Env Sciences

para.literalLayout: Lake Level measurements are carried out each austral summer season for the lakes of the McMurdo Dry Valleys, Antactica

Data contained in these files has been subjected to quality control standards imposed by the investigator. The user of this data should be aware that, while efforts have been taken to ensure that these data are of the highest quality, there is no guarantee of perfection for the data contained herein and the possibility of errors exists. If you encounter questionable data, please contact the MCM LTER data manager corrected or qualified. Thus, these data may be modified and future data will be appended.

section.title: MCM LTER data may be used freely with the following restrictions:

para.literalLayout: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications.
A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to the McMurdo data manager and principal investigator.
The end-user follow the guidelines set forth in the LTER Network Data Access Policy, Data Access Requirements, and General Data Use Agreement found at http://www.mcmlter.org/data_guidelines.htm

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Lake Fryxell and Lake Hoare are in the Taylor Valley, Southern Victoria Land, Antarctica (77 degrees S, 162 degrees E). Lake Fryxell has a maximum depth of 20m and is a permanently stratified meromictic lake with a conductivity of 1.2 to 2.0 mS/cm in the upper mixomolimnion and 4.1 to 8.4 mS/cm in the lower anoxic monomolimnion. Water temperatures during the summer range from 0.01 degrees C to 2.7 degrees C, with temperature increasing with depth. The chemocline is situated at 9.5m. In contrast, Lake Hoare is unstratified during the summer and is freshwater. It has a maximum depth of 34m. Summer temperatures in the water column ranged between 0.01 degrees C and 1.0 degrees C. Lake Bonney, West Lake Bonney, Lake Vanda, Lake Vida, Lake Joyce, Don Juan Pond and Lake Miers are also in the McMurdo Dry Valleys of Antarctica.

para.literalLayout:
Lake leveling has been achieved by optical surveys made whenever possible. At least the first data point in each file was made by Trevor Chinn’s group as one of their last surveys in the valleys. We have made an attempt to reference all of our observations to the historical (and published) record from the dry valleys. That means that while the values in meters above sea level are correct with respect to the old KIWI data, they will not match differential GPS measurements made without correcting to the KIWI datum.
During MCM-I we established new lake leveling benchmarks at the three main Taylor Valley camps for ease of measurement. Each of these new benchmarks has been measured using differential GPS to a high degree of accuracy. To put lake levels in the context of the historical data, a similar GPS survey was carried out on old Kiwi benchmarks that have been used for leveling in the past, and an offset applied to the data collected from the new benchmarks.
See the following PDF file for photographs of the Dry Valleys Lake Level benchmarks: http://www.mcmlter.org/data/lakes/physical/core/dv_lake_level_benchmarks.pdf

attribute.attributeDefinition: Code that identifies the table in the database. LIMNO_LAKE_LEVELS, in this case.

textDomain.definition: Code string to identify the name of the table in the database, LIMNO_LAKE_LEVELS in this case

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of lake where measurement was made

textDomain.definition: Name of lake where measurement was made

attribute.attributeDefinition: Date on which measurement was made
This is the old benchmark used for lake leveling that the new measurements are corrected to

textDomain.definition: This is the old benchmark used for lake leveling that the new measurements are corrected to

attribute.attributeDefinition: This is the benchmark the optical survey was actually performed on. The lake level below this datum is recorded with level and stadia rod
Lake level below datum is expressed as meters above sea level (masl) in terms of the reference benchmark.
usually lists the surveyors. All measurements are made to true water level in drilled holes or in a connected moat. Some are shot to the surface of the moat ice and if so, that is noted here (rare)
